attributes.title: What is the potential for solar parks in the UK to enhance soil carbon through active management? A rapid systematic review of the available evidence.
attributes.description: This project aims to provide a systematic review of the scientific literature to examine the effects of plant diversity (taxonomic, functional or phylogenetic diversities) and vegetation management (mowing, grazing and nutrient addition) on soil carbon in grasslands. The understanding will be used to infer the potential for solar parks in the UK to enhance soil carbon through active land and biodiversity management of hosting grassland ecosystems. Version 1.1 (v1.1) of the review protocol was uploaded on 31st March 2020 and updated on 9th April 2020 (v1.2). Version 1.2 is the currently updated review protocol used for the systematic literature review, and is viewable from within the live project page (https://doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/GXTM5).

attributes.title: DSE: Conflict, lingering attachment, parent adjustment, and parent-child interactions after divorce
attributes.description: This secondary data analysis study seeks to test the well-documented phenomenon of the "spillover effect," where parents' experience of emotional distress or well-being after divorce can impact their interactions with their children. We will use data from a larger, longitudinal study of adult adjustment after divorce. In addition, we will explore the role of theoretical predictors and mediational processes that may further elucidate the nature of the spillover phenomenon.

attributes.title: Effectiveness of information-based versus structural interventions on food choices by socioeconomic position: a randomized controlled trial in an experimental online supermarket
attributes.description:
People of lower socioeconomic position (SEP) are more likely to have obesity than people of higher SEP and SEP inequities in obesity in Europe are widening (World Health Organization, 2014). Lower socioeconomic position (SEP) is associated with a more energy dense diet (Aggarwal et al., 2011; Monsivais & Drewnowski, 2009). Consumption of more energy dense foods has been consistently linked to higher energy intake in experimental studies (Karl & Roberts, 2014) and results from prospective cohort studies have shown a positive association between energy density (ED) of the total diet and BMI (Karl & Roberts, 2014). Thus, the association between SEP and obesity may be mediated, in part, by the consumption of a more energy-dense diet (Drewnowski & Specter, 2004). Interventions that reduce dietary energy density would benefit public health, particularly among people of lower SEP.

In the UK, 26% of the adults eat meals out one or more times per week and 20% eat takeaway meals at home one or more times per week, suggesting that the major part of the meals consists in food prepared at home (Goffe et al., 2017). People from lower SEP tend to spend a greater proportion of their average food expenditure on prepared-at-home produce (such as products purchased in supermarkets) as opposed to catering services than people of higher SEP (lowest equivalised disposable income decile group: 74% vs. highest: 60%) (Office for National Statistics, 2019). Thus, nutrition interventions targeting supermarket purchases provide an opportunity to benefit the diet of all of the population and people of lower SEP in particular.

Information-based nutrition interventions are one of the most common approaches to improving diet (Capewell & Capewell, 2017; Frieden, 2010). An example of an information-based intervention is menu energy labelling in restaurants (VanEpps et al., 2016). This type of interventions has been suggested to be less effective among people of lower compared to higher SEP (Beauchamp et al., 2014; Sarink et al., 2016). However, systematic reviews of the impact of menu energy labelling has highlighted the limited quality of evidence supporting this hypothesis (Crockett et al., 2018; Sarink et al., 2016). It has been suggested that structural interventions that target core features of the food environment (i.e., reducing portion sizes, increasing the availability of heathier food options) and require individuals to use a low level of agency may be most effective and most equitable (Adams et al., 2016; Backholer et al., 2014; Capewell & Capewell, 2017). However, there is a lack of empirical evidence to support this hypothesis.

Information-based interventions typically rely on people being motivated by health in their food choices (Dubé & Cantin, 2000). Yet, health may be a less influential motive for food choice among people of lower SEP (Pepper & Nettle, 2017). Thus, SEP based differences in food choice motives, and notably health motivation, may explain why information-based interventions could be less effective among people of lower vs. higher SEP.

The aim of this study is to examine how an information-based intervention (labelling of lower ED food products) and a structural intervention (greater proportion of lower ED options in food product ranges) affect the ED of food purchases within a virtual online supermarket (Forwood et al., 2015) in participants of lower vs. higher SEP. The primary hypothesis is that labelling will reduce the ED of virtual online supermarket food purchases to a greater extent in participants of higher SEP vs. lower SEP. Conversely, we hypothesise that a greater proportion of lower ED options will decrease the ED of food purchases equally among participants of lower and higher SEP. The secondary hypothesis is that differences in health-based food choice motives in participants of lower vs. higher SEP will mediate the differential effect that ED labelling has on ED of food purchases among participants of lower vs. higher SEP.

q2.value:
The aim of this study is to examine how an information-based intervention (labelling of lower ED food products) and a structural intervention (greater proportion of lower ED options in food product ranges) affect the ED of food purchases within a virtual online supermarket in participants of lower vs. higher socio-economic position (SEP).

The primary hypothesis is that labelling will reduce the ED of virtual online supermarket food purchases to a greater extent in participants of higher SEP vs. lower SEP. Conversely, we hypothesise that a greater proportion of lower ED options will decrease the ED of food purchases equally among participants of lower and higher SEP.

The secondary hypothesis is that differences in health-based food choice motives in participants of lower vs. higher SEP will mediate the differential effect that ED labelling has on ED of food purchases among participants of lower vs. higher SEP.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study will be a 2x2 randomised controlled trial with information-based intervention (no ED labelling / ED labelling) and structural intervention (default proportion / increased proportion of lower ED food items) as between-subject factors and ED (kcal/g) of food purchases during an online supermarket-shopping task as dependent variable.

This study will use an online supermarket platform (www.woodssupermarket.co.uk) developed to mimic an online supermarket website and the participants will be asked to complete a shopping task using a pre-determined shopping list of 10 items:

A packet of biscuits
A standard sized loaf of bread 
A chilled pizza
An ice cream tub
A chilled ready meal for one
A pack of sausages
A sharing bag of crisps or savoury snacks
A pre-packed piece of cheese
A pack of yogurts
A jar of jam or sweet spread

q7.value: All the participants will be randomly allocated to one of the four experimental conditions in Qualtrics with the same number of participants in each of the four groups.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through an online recruitment panel (Prolific) in which participants are compensated proportionate to the time it takes to complete the online study (≈ £5/hour reward participants). Participants’ recruitment will be stratified by gender (50% male, 50% female), student status (3.5% yes and 96.5% no) and qualification levels to be representative of England population.

Inclusion criteria

•	UK residents, aged ≥ 18 years
•	Fluent in English
•	Have access to a computer and Internet
•	Responsible for a substantial proportion of household grocery shopping

Exclusion criteria

•	Unable to provide informed consent and to comply with the study requirements
•	Any of the following dietary restrictions:
o	Vegetarian
o	Vegan
o	Gluten-free
o	Sugar-free
o	Dairy/lactose-free
o	Food allergy (e.g. milk, eggs, nut, wheat, fish, etc.)

q12.value:
To observe differences between the intervention groups and interaction with SEP

In a previous study (n=1,088) using the online supermarket platform, two types of nutritional interventions targeting a reduction of saturated fat (SFA) were compared: 1/ altering the default order of products in ascending order of SFA content 2/ offering explicit swaps with lower SFA (Koutoukidis et al., 2019). This study showed a large main effect (f=0.42) of altering the default order: -4.78% (95%IC: -5.43 to -4.12) of energy from SFA; and a small-to-medium main effect (f=0.12) of offering swaps: -1.48% (95%IC: -2.19 to -0.76) of energy from SFA. Regarding ED reduction, this study showed a small-to-medium main effect (f=0.14) of altering the default order: -5.16 (95%IC: -7.3 to -3.02); and no significant main effect (f=0.04) of offering swaps -1.5 (95% IC: -3.65 to 0.67).

Based on these previous results, we will power our analyses to detect small main effects (f=0.1) of the labelling and increased proportion interventions. In an ANCOVA including four groups (control, labelling, increased proportion, increased proportion & labelling) and one covariate (level of education), to detect a main effect of labelling or increased proportion we will require a sample size of 788 participants (197 per group) for 80% power at α = 0.05 (GPower 3.1).

A sample size of 788 participants will allow to detect small interaction effects (f=0.1) of labelling or increased proportion with level of education in an ANCOVA including four groups (control, labelling, increased proportion, increased proportion & labelling) and one covariate (level of education) for 80% power at α = 0.05 (GPower 3.1).

To observe a mediated effect of SEP through health and weight control motives

Based on existing literature we hypothesise that the relationship between SEP and food choice motives will be small-to-medium in size (Pechey et al., 2015). Moreover, in a previous trial we ran using a virtual fast food restaurant (osf.io/ajcr6), we found a small-to-medium correlation between level of education and healthiness motivation (r=0.17) as well as small-to-medium correlation between healthiness motivation and kcal ordered (r=-0.25). Empirical estimates of sample sizes needed for 0.8 power in mediation analyses indicate that samples of ≈ 380 are sufficient to detect mediation through pathways that are small and small-to-moderate in statistical size using bias-corrected bootstrap tests (Fritz & Mackinnon, 2007). Thus, a sample of 788 participants (i.e., 394 per labelling or proportion condition) allow for adequate power in our planned moderated mediation analysis.

We will recruit a sample of 1,000 participants (= participants who completed the entire study) to account for potential data loss due to incorrect answers, technical problems, failed attention checks, no compliance with the shopping task (up to ~20%) resulting in a minimum sample of 788 participants for our primary analyses.

Fritz, M. S., & Mackinnon, D. P. (2007). Required Sample Size to Detect the Mediated Effect. Psychological Science, 18(3), 233–239. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-9280.2007.01882.x.Required
Koutoukidis, D. A., Jebb, S. A., Ordóñez-mena, J. M., Noreik, M., Tsiountsioura, M., Kennedy, S., Payne-riches, S., Aveyard, P., Ordonez-mena, J., Noreik, M., Tsiountsioura, M., Kennedy, S., Riches, S. P., Aveyard, P., & Piernas, C. (2019). Effectiveness of interventions to reduce the saturated fat content of food purchases: a factorial randomised controlled trial in an experimental online supermarket. IJBNPA, 1–14.
Pechey, R., Monsivais, P., Ng, Y. L., & Marteau, T. M. (2015). Why don’t poor men eat fruit? Socioeconomic differences in motivations for fruit consumption. Appetite, 84, 271–279. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.appet.2014.10.022

question.value:
Primary outcome

The main outcome variable is the mean ED of the food items purchased (kcal/100g)

Secondary outcomes

From the shopping task:
	Total energy (kcal) of the foods purchased
	Energy from total sugar (% of total energy)
	Energy from saturated fatty acids (SFA) (% of total energy)
	Salt content (g/100g)
	Proportion of lower ED foods in the basket of foods purchased
	Cost (£, £/100g and £/100kcal) of the foods purchased

From the debriefing questionnaire:
	Validity: mean of item “I would normally buy [the 10 items on the shopping list]” for all the food items coded as: 1 = Never; 2 = Very rarely; 3 = Rarely; 4 = Occasionally; 5 = Frequently; 6 = Very frequently.
	Kcal influence: answer to the item “The choices I made during online shopping were influenced by how many calories I thought were in the options available.” coded as: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Slightly disagree; 4 = Neutral; 5 = Slightly agree; 6 = Agree; 7 = Strongly agree

Independent variables

Highest educational qualification will be coded from 1 to 9: 1 = No formal qualifications; 2 = 1–3 GCSEs; 3 = 4+ GCSEs; 4 = A level; 5 = Certificate of higher education (CertHE); 6 = Diploma of higher education (DipHE); 7 = Bachelor; 8 = Master’s degree; 9 = Doctorate, and as a binary variable as lower (values: 1, 2, 3, 4 ) or higher (values: 5, 6, 7, 8, 9).

Years in higher education, as a continuous variable

Level of education (composite score): In order to account for years in higher education and highest education qualification when characterising each participants’ education level, we will z-score the two variables and create an average of the two to form a composite score called ‘level of education’.

Equivalised household disposable income: The OECD-modified equivalence scale will be used to adjust household income, taking into account household size and composition. Equivalised income will be calculated by dividing the after tax household income by the sum of the equivalence value of all the household members: first adult = 1, additional adult or child aged 14 and over = 0.5, child aged 0-13 = 0.3.

Subjective SEP: The measure of the Subjective Social Status using the MacArthur Scale will be coded from 1 to 10.

Health and weight control food choice motives
Both health and weight control scores will be computed by averaging ratings for individual items of each dimension (health motivation: 6 items; weight control motivation: 4 items). Response options range from 1 to 4: 1 = Not at all important; 2 = A little important; 3 = Moderately important; 4 = Very important. Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated as an indicator of internal consistency in order to compare our data with the original study that developed this measure.

BMI: Self-reported height will be recalculated into height in metres (1 ft = 0.3048 m, 1 in = 0.0254 m). Self-reported weight will be recalculated into weight in kilograms. (1 stone = 6.35029 kg, 1 lb = 0.453592 kg). BMI will be calculated as weight (kg) / height (m2). BMI data will be trimmed for implausible values excluding weight for less than 30 kg and more than 250 kg, height for less than 145 cm and more than 3m, BMI < 14 or BMI > 48.

Aim guessing: Participants who identify the aim of the study as being to examine the influence of labelling or increased proportion of lower ED/healthier food items on food purchases will be coded as being aware of the study aims. Responses will be independently coded by two researchers, with discrepancies in coding decisions resolved by a third researcher.

Primary analyses

The measure of SEP used in our primary analysis will be the level of education because previous research showed that people of higher education were more likely to use nutrition labels (Breck et al., 2014; Cowburn & Stockley, 2008).

ANCOVA will be used to test the effect of labelling (categorical variable: yes or no), proportion (categorical variable: default or increased), level of education (continuous variable) and labelling*level of education and proportion*level of education interactions on the mean ED of foods purchased. If this analysis reveals the predicted significant interaction between labelling or proportion condition and the continuous measure of level of education on mean ED, we will further examine the nature of the interactions by conducting floodlight analysis (Spiller et al., 2013). We will calculate the Johnson–Neyman point defined as the value of educational level for which the effect of labelling (or proportion) reaches statistical significance (Johnson & Neyman, 1936). Values of level of education above this point will correspond to significant differences between the labelling and no labelling conditions (resp. the default and increased proportion conditions) whereas values below the point will not. The floodlight analysis will be run using the SAS macro developed by Hayes & Matthes, 2009 (Hayes & Matthes, 2009).

Sensitivity analyses

Sensitivity analyses will be conducted to examine whether the pattern of results from the primary analyses differ after excluding participants guessing the aims of the study. We will repeat our main analyses with a more stringent criteria for having completed the shopping task as intended (excluding any participants who did not select 10 items in total and 1 item from each category on the shopping list). We will also repeat the main analysis substituting the composite variable level of education by years in higher education as a continuous covariate (ANCOVA) and by highest educational qualification split into lower vs. higher qualification levels as a binary covariate (2x2x2 ANOVA).

We will report whether sensitivity analyses result in deviations from the pattern of significance to the main analyses (i.e., any significant differences between conditions becoming not significant, and vice versa).

Secondary analyses

Moderated mediation analysis

We will describe health and weight control motivation in the overall sample using mean and standard deviation and report the correlation (Pearson’s) between the health and weight control motivation scores and level of education.

If the primary analyses suggest that level of education moderates the effect of labelling or proportion on the mean ED of foods purchased (i.e., the labelling*level of education or proportion*level of education interaction is significant), mediation analyses will be performed in order to examine the extent to which 1/ health food choice motive, 2/ weight control food choice motive mediates the effect of level of education on the mean ED.

The moderated mediation will be tested by estimating the conditional indirect effect of level of education on the mean ED through M for labelling and no labelling conditions (resp. the default and increased proportion conditions) and testing the conditional indirect effect for those conditions using bias-corrected bootstrap. We will use the PROCESS macro (Model 15) on SAS software that provides asymmetric bias-corrected bootstrap confidence intervals for inference about the conditional indirect effects using 5,000 bootstrap samples (Hayes, 2012). Moderated mediation will be tested by determining whether or not the confidence interval for the difference between conditional indirect effects for labelling vs. no labelling conditions (resp. the increased and baseline availability conditions) contains zero.

Analyses of secondary outcomes

For descriptive purposes we will code each participant product selection based on the food categories outlined in the shopping list and repeat the primary analysis strategy on each of the 10 food categories individually.

To further investigate the effect of the interventions and level of education, we will repeat the primary analysis strategy with the following dependent variables:
-	on total energy of the foods purchased;
-	on energy from total sugar;
-	on energy from SFA;
-	on salt content;
-	on proportion of lower ED foods in the basket of foods purchased;
-	on cost of the foods purchased.

We will also repeat the primary analysis including the interaction between labelling and proportion in the model.

Debriefing questionnaire

We will explore whether the shopping list was valid and the extent to which participants reported being influenced by calorie content when making food choices. Responses to the debriefing questionnaire will be analysed.
-	We will report the distribution of responses for validity and kcal influence (mean, SD, median, quartiles Q1 and Q3) in the overall sample.
-	Two ANCOVAs will be run (as in primary analysis) to test the effect of labelling, proportion and level of education on (a) validity and (b) kcal influence to investigate whether the responses differ across conditions and SEP.

For the labelling conditions only, we will report the percentage of participants who know what the “healthier choice” badge means, i.e., who tick the answer “Fewer calories per gram option”.

Breck, A., Cantor, J., Martinez, O., & Elbel, B. (2014). Who reports noticing and using calorie information posted on fast food restaurant menus? Appetite, 81, 30–36. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.appet.2014.05.027
Cowburn, G., & Stockley, L. (2008). Consumer understanding and use of nutrition labelling: a systematic review. Public Health Nutrition, 8(01). https://doi.org/10.1079/phn2004666
Hayes, A. F. (2012). PROCESS: A Versatile Computational Tool for Observed Variable Mediation, Moderation, and Conditional Process Modeling. White Paper. http://www.afhayes.com/ public/process2012.pdf
Hayes, A. F., & Matthes, J. (2009). Computational procedures for probing interactions in OLS and logistic regression: SPSS and SAS implementations. Behavior Research Methods, 41(3), 924–936. https://doi.org/10.3758/BRM.41.3.924
Johnson, P. O., & Neyman, J. (1936). Tests of Certain Linear Hypotheses and Their Application to Some Educational Problems. Statistical Research Memoirs, 1, 57–93.
Spiller, S. A., Fitzsimons, G. J., Lynch, J. G., & Mcclelland, G. H. (2013). Spotlights, Floodlights, and the Magic Number Zero: Simple Effects Tests in Moderated Regression. Journal of Marketing Research, 50(2), 277–288. https://doi.org/10.1509/jmr.12.0420

q19.value: All statistical analyses will be performed using SAS version 9.3 (SAS Institute, Inc., 2012 SAS® 9.3. Cary, NC). The level of significance will be set at p < 0.05 for primary and sensitivity analyses and at p < 0.01 for secondary analyses.

q20.value:
Only participants who have completed the entire study (i.e., baseline assessments + online shopping task + questionnaires) will be included in the analysis. Participants who will have failed at least one attention check or have not complied with the shopping task will be excluded.

Two attention checks will be included:
-	In the baseline questionnaire, item 9: This is an attention check. How many times have you visited the planet Mars? Several times / Just once / Never. Correct answer: Never
-	In the food choice questionnaire, item 7: This is an attention check. Please choose the answer 2 ‘Not important’. Correct answer: 2 ‘Not important’.

We will analyse data from participants who bought at least 5 items out of 10 categories of the shopping list  and, if participants buy more than the 10 items requested, as in previous research we will include all items bought. Outcome measures will be based on all the foods in the shopping baskets.

q21.value: We do not anticipate missing data for analysis of the primary outcome for the population because ED is calculated based on the food database embedded in the online supermarket platform. We do not anticipate missing data either for the dependant variables because the questionnaires will not allow missing answers. Data from participants who start but not finish the study will not be included. Any a posteriori withdrawal will be reported and reasons for withdrawal will be documented (e.g., incorrect answers, technical problems).

Thus, a sample of 788 participants (i.e., 394 per labelling or proportion condition) allow for adequate power in our planned moderated mediation analysis.

We will recruit a sample of 1,000 participants (= participants who completed the entire study) to account for potential data loss due to incorrect answers, technical problems, failed attention checks, no compliance with the shopping task (up to ~20%) resulting in a minimum sample of 788 participants for our primary analyses.

Fritz, M. S., & Mackinnon, D. P. (2007). Required Sample Size to Detect the Mediated Effect. Psychological Science, 18(3), 233–239. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-9280.2007.01882.x.Required

Effectiveness of interventions to reduce the saturated fat content of food purchases: a factorial randomised controlled trial in an experimental online supermarket. IJBNPA, 1–14.
Pechey, R., Monsivais, P., Ng, Y. L., & Marteau, T. M. (2015). Why don’t poor men eat fruit? Socioeconomic differences in motivations for fruit consumption. Appetite, 84, 271–279. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.appet.2014.10.022
registration_responses.q19: All statistical analyses will be performed using SAS version 9.3 (SAS Institute, Inc., 2012 SAS® 9.3. Cary, NC). The level of significance will be set at p < 0.05 for primary and sensitivity analyses and at p < 0.01 for secondary analyses.
registration_responses.q20:
Only participants who have completed the entire study (i.e., baseline assessments + online shopping task + questionnaires) will be included in the analysis. Participants who will have failed at least one attention check or have not complied with the shopping task will be excluded.

Two attention checks will be included:
-	In the baseline questionnaire, item 9: This is an attention check. How many times have you visited the planet Mars? Several times / Just once / Never. Correct answer: Never
-	In the food choice questionnaire, item 7: This is an attention check. Please choose the answer 2 ‘Not important’. Correct answer: 2 ‘Not important’.

We will analyse data from participants who bought at least 5 items out of 10 categories of the shopping list  and, if participants buy more than the 10 items requested, as in previous research we will include all items bought. Outcome measures will be based on all the foods in the shopping baskets.
registration_responses.q21: We do not anticipate missing data for analysis of the primary outcome for the population because ED is calculated based on the food database embedded in the online supermarket platform. We do not anticipate missing data either for the dependant variables because the questionnaires will not allow missing answers. Data from participants who start but not finish the study will not be included. Any a posteriori withdrawal will be reported and reasons for withdrawal will be documented (e.g., incorrect answers, technical problems).
registration_responses.q6.question:
This study will be a 2x2 randomised controlled trial with information-based intervention (no ED labelling / ED labelling) and structural intervention (default proportion / increased proportion of lower ED food items) as between-subject factors and ED (kcal/g) of food purchases during an online supermarket-shopping task as dependent variable.

This study will use an online supermarket platform (www.woodssupermarket.co.uk) developed to mimic an online supermarket website and the participants will be asked to complete a shopping task using a pre-determined shopping list of 10 items:

A packet of biscuits
A standard sized loaf of bread 
A chilled pizza
An ice cream tub
A chilled ready meal for one
A pack of sausages
A sharing bag of crisps or savoury snacks
A pre-packed piece of cheese
A pack of yogurts
A jar of jam or sweet spread
registration_responses.q10.question:
Participants will be recruited through an online recruitment panel (Prolific) in which participants are compensated proportionate to the time it takes to complete the online study (≈ £5/hour reward participants). Participants’ recruitment will be stratified by gender (50% male, 50% female), student status (3.5% yes and 96.5% no) and qualification levels to be representative of England population.

Inclusion criteria

•	UK residents, aged ≥ 18 years
•	Fluent in English
•	Have access to a computer and Internet
•	Responsible for a substantial proportion of household grocery shopping

Exclusion criteria

•	Unable to provide informed consent and to comply with the study requirements
•	Any of the following dietary restrictions:
o	Vegetarian
o	Vegan
o	Gluten-free
o	Sugar-free
o	Dairy/lactose-free
o	Food allergy (e.g. milk, eggs, nut, wheat, fish, etc.)
registration_responses.q15.question:
Primary outcome

The main outcome variable is the mean ED of the food items purchased (kcal/100g)

Secondary outcomes

From the shopping task:
	Total energy (kcal) of the foods purchased
	Energy from total sugar (% of total energy)
	Energy from saturated fatty acids (SFA) (% of total energy)
	Salt content (g/100g)
	Proportion of lower ED foods in the basket of foods purchased
	Cost (£, £/100g and £/100kcal) of the foods purchased

From the debriefing questionnaire:
	Validity: mean of item “I would normally buy [the 10 items on the shopping list]” for all the food items coded as: 1 = Never; 2 = Very rarely; 3 = Rarely; 4 = Occasionally; 5 = Frequently; 6 = Very frequently.
	Kcal influence: answer to the item “The choices I made during online shopping were influenced by how many calories I thought were in the options available.” coded as: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Slightly disagree; 4 = Neutral; 5 = Slightly agree; 6 = Agree; 7 = Strongly agree

Independent variables

Highest educational qualification will be coded from 1 to 9: 1 = No formal qualifications; 2 = 1–3 GCSEs; 3 = 4+ GCSEs; 4 = A level; 5 = Certificate of higher education (CertHE); 6 = Diploma of higher education (DipHE); 7 = Bachelor; 8 = Master’s degree; 9 = Doctorate, and as a binary variable as lower (values: 1, 2, 3, 4 ) or higher (values: 5, 6, 7, 8, 9).

Years in higher education, as a continuous variable

Level of education (composite score): In order to account for years in higher education and highest education qualification when characterising each participants’ education level, we will z-score the two variables and create an average of the two to form a composite score called ‘level of education’.

Equivalised household disposable income: The OECD-modified equivalence scale will be used to adjust household income, taking into account household size and composition. Equivalised income will be calculated by dividing the after tax household income by the sum of the equivalence value of all the household members: first adult = 1, additional adult or child aged 14 and over = 0.5, child aged 0-13 = 0.3.

Subjective SEP: The measure of the Subjective Social Status using the MacArthur Scale will be coded from 1 to 10.

Health and weight control food choice motives
Both health and weight control scores will be computed by averaging ratings for individual items of each dimension (health motivation: 6 items; weight control motivation: 4 items). Response options range from 1 to 4: 1 = Not at all important; 2 = A little important; 3 = Moderately important; 4 = Very important. Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated as an indicator of internal consistency in order to compare our data with the original study that developed this measure.

BMI: Self-reported height will be recalculated into height in metres (1 ft = 0.3048 m, 1 in = 0.0254 m). Self-reported weight will be recalculated into weight in kilograms. (1 stone = 6.35029 kg, 1 lb = 0.453592 kg). BMI will be calculated as weight (kg) / height (m2). BMI data will be trimmed for implausible values excluding weight for less than 30 kg and more than 250 kg, height for less than 145 cm and more than 3m, BMI < 14 or BMI > 48.

Aim guessing: Participants who identify the aim of the study as being to examine the influence of labelling or increased proportion of lower ED/healthier food items on food purchases will be coded as being aware of the study aims. Responses will be independently coded by two researchers, with discrepancies in coding decisions resolved by a third researcher.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Primary analyses

The measure of SEP used in our primary analysis will be the level of education because previous research showed that people of higher education were more likely to use nutrition labels (Breck et al., 2014; Cowburn & Stockley, 2008).

ANCOVA will be used to test the effect of labelling (categorical variable: yes or no), proportion (categorical variable: default or increased), level of education (continuous variable) and labelling*level of education and proportion*level of education interactions on the mean ED of foods purchased. If this analysis reveals the predicted significant interaction between labelling or proportion condition and the continuous measure of level of education on mean ED, we will further examine the nature of the interactions by conducting floodlight analysis (Spiller et al., 2013). We will calculate the Johnson–Neyman point defined as the value of educational level for which the effect of labelling (or proportion) reaches statistical significance (Johnson & Neyman, 1936). Values of level of education above this point will correspond to significant differences between the labelling and no labelling conditions (resp. the default and increased proportion conditions) whereas values below the point will not. The floodlight analysis will be run using the SAS macro developed by Hayes & Matthes, 2009 (Hayes & Matthes, 2009).

Sensitivity analyses

Sensitivity analyses will be conducted to examine whether the pattern of results from the primary analyses differ after excluding participants guessing the aims of the study. We will repeat our main analyses with a more stringent criteria for having completed the shopping task as intended (excluding any participants who did not select 10 items in total and 1 item from each category on the shopping list). We will also repeat the main analysis substituting the composite variable level of education by years in higher education as a continuous covariate (ANCOVA) and by highest educational qualification split into lower vs. higher qualification levels as a binary covariate (2x2x2 ANOVA).

We will report whether sensitivity analyses result in deviations from the pattern of significance to the main analyses (i.e., any significant differences between conditions becoming not significant, and vice versa).

Secondary analyses

Moderated mediation analysis

We will describe health and weight control motivation in the overall sample using mean and standard deviation and report the correlation (Pearson’s) between the health and weight control motivation scores and level of education.

If the primary analyses suggest that level of education moderates the effect of labelling or proportion on the mean ED of foods purchased (i.e., the labelling*level of education or proportion*level of education interaction is significant), mediation analyses will be performed in order to examine the extent to which 1/ health food choice motive, 2/ weight control food choice motive mediates the effect of level of education on the mean ED.

The moderated mediation will be tested by estimating the conditional indirect effect of level of education on the mean ED through M for labelling and no labelling conditions (resp. the default and increased proportion conditions) and testing the conditional indirect effect for those conditions using bias-corrected bootstrap. We will use the PROCESS macro (Model 15) on SAS software that provides asymmetric bias-corrected bootstrap confidence intervals for inference about the conditional indirect effects using 5,000 bootstrap samples (Hayes, 2012). Moderated mediation will be tested by determining whether or not the confidence interval for the difference between conditional indirect effects for labelling vs. no labelling conditions (resp. the increased and baseline availability conditions) contains zero.

Analyses of secondary outcomes

For descriptive purposes we will code each participant product selection based on the food categories outlined in the shopping list and repeat the primary analysis strategy on each of the 10 food categories individually.

To further investigate the effect of the interventions and level of education, we will repeat the primary analysis strategy with the following dependent variables:
-	on total energy of the foods purchased;
-	on energy from total sugar;
-	on energy from SFA;
-	on salt content;
-	on proportion of lower ED foods in the basket of foods purchased;
-	on cost of the foods purchased.

We will also repeat the primary analysis including the interaction between labelling and proportion in the model.

Debriefing questionnaire

We will explore whether the shopping list was valid and the extent to which participants reported being influenced by calorie content when making food choices. Responses to the debriefing questionnaire will be analysed.
-	We will report the distribution of responses for validity and kcal influence (mean, SD, median, quartiles Q1 and Q3) in the overall sample.
-	Two ANCOVAs will be run (as in primary analysis) to test the effect of labelling, proportion and level of education on (a) validity and (b) kcal influence to investigate whether the responses differ across conditions and SEP.

For the labelling conditions only, we will report the percentage of participants who know what the “healthier choice” badge means, i.e., who tick the answer “Fewer calories per gram option”.

Breck, A., Cantor, J., Martinez, O., & Elbel, B. (2014). Who reports noticing and using calorie information posted on fast food restaurant menus? Appetite, 81, 30–36. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.appet.2014.05.027
Cowburn, G., & Stockley, L. (2008). Consumer understanding and use of nutrition labelling: a systematic review. Public Health Nutrition, 8(01). https://doi.org/10.1079/phn2004666
Hayes, A. F. (2012). PROCESS: A Versatile Computational Tool for Observed Variable Mediation, Moderation, and Conditional Process Modeling. White Paper. http://www.afhayes.com/ public/process2012.pdf
Hayes, A. F., & Matthes, J. (2009). Computational procedures for probing interactions in OLS and logistic regression: SPSS and SAS implementations. Behavior Research Methods, 41(3), 924–936. https://doi.org/10.3758/BRM.41.3.924
Johnson, P. O., & Neyman, J. (1936). Tests of Certain Linear Hypotheses and Their Application to Some Educational Problems. Statistical Research Memoirs, 1, 57–93.
Spiller, S. A., Fitzsimons, G. J., Lynch, J. G., & Mcclelland, G. H. (2013). Spotlights, Floodlights, and the Magic Number Zero: Simple Effects Tests in Moderated Regression. Journal of Marketing Research, 50(2), 277–288. https://doi.org/10.1509/jmr.12.0420

attributes.title: Websites' halo effect (trusworthines) is modulated by the presence of human faces.
attributes.description: Despite the large body of literature on the relationship between perceived faces' aesthetic and trustworthiness, little is known about (1) the implication of the presence of a face in a surrounding context, (2) the role of ethnicity, gender, and age on the strength of the relationship, and (3) if are there any differences between implicit and explicit estimation of the strength of the effect.

q1.value: Websites' halo effect (trusworthines) is modulated by the presence of human faces in websites.

q2.value: Giulio Gabrieli, Carlotta Gualco, Andrea Bizzego, Gianluca Esposito

q3.value: Despite the large body of literature on the relationship between perceived faces' aesthetic and trustworthiness, little is known about (1) the implication of the presence of a face in a surrounding context, (2) the role of ethnicity, gender, and age on the strength of the relationship, and (3) if are there any differences between implicit and explicit estimation of the strength of the effect.

q4.value:
We hypothesize that:
1) the strength of the relationship between aesthetic and trust (pearson_r), as well as the heart rate variability and the EDA response,  is affected by the age of presented stimuli, but not by their gender or participants' exposure to different websites. (H1, H2, H3)
2) Trust (H4) and Aesthetic (H5) ratings are affected by the presence of a face within the same website, such that that Trust and Aesthetics are higher when a pleasant face is present, , lower when an unpleasant face is present, and middle when no face is present (unpleasant < no face < pleasant). Moreover, we hypothesize an interaction effect within Face (unpleasant, pleasant, no face) and participants' conservatism level (high|level)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Participants (N = 40) will be shown images of websites (N=72) and emotional images (N = 24), while their physiological activity (ECG, EDA). Moreover, after each picture, participants will be asked to rate on a 5-point Likert scale how much they like the presented image and, if the image is a website, how much they trust that website. 
At the end of the session, participants will be asked to complete a survey on their browsing habits and one on their conservatism attitudes.

Emotional images are drawn from the IAPS dataset, while websites' images are obtained by photomanipulated versions of websites' images from the AVI14 dataset, by applying images of faces (all 250x250), used in a previous work.

q9.value: images will be presented in a randomized order, such that after every 2 website images an emotional image will be presented.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants (all caucasian female) will be recruited amongst the student of the University of Trento (Italy). Participants will receive no monetary compensation but may receive credits if they are enrolled in the Bs. of Psychology or Ms. in Neuroscience)

q13.value: N = 36 Caucasian females aged at least 18.

q14.value:
A power analysis conducted in G*Power, for a 2X3 mixed between within-subjects ANOVA, for alpha = 0.01 and Power = 0.95, reported that in order to detect a medium-size effect (f = 0.30) we will require, for hypothesis H4 and H5, 36 participants. 

Since a higher number of participants would be required in the same condition for H1, H2, and H3, in order to not overpower H4 and H5 we will accept a lower power for H1, H2, H3. A power analysis for a 5*2 within between factors ANOVA (3 within, 2 between), considering alpha = 0.01 and effect size f = 0.30, suggests that with 36 participants we should be able to achieve a power between 0.85 and 0.90

q15.value:
We will stop once N = 36 participants have been recruited. 
Because of time constraints for different thesis writing, we will perform a preliminary analysis with the data collected up to May 15th. 
Independently from the results, we will continue collecting data after May 15th if the predefined sample size (36) is not reached.

question.value:
Age: age of the presented face. Can be Child or Adult.
Gender: Gender of the presented face. It can be Male or Female.
Ethnicity: ethnicity of the presented face. It can be Caucasian or Asian

Trust: perceived trust of the person toward a website, on a 1 to 5 scale
Aesthetic: the perceived aesthetic of the person toward a website, on a 1 to 5 scale
Conservationism: conservationism score on the X Scale.
Exposure: participant exposure to different websites, defined as follow:
For what concerns Conservatism and Exposure, a median split will be adopted to divide the participants in an High | Low exposure and High | Low conservatism groups.

We will use 3 3X4 repeated measures ANOVA with 3 within-subjects (Age, Gender, Ethnicity) and one between-subject, Exposure) factors to analyze our results. DV will be (H1) pearson_r between Aesthetic and Trust, (H2) HRV, and (H3) EDA variability.
Moreover, we will employ 2 2x3 repeated measure ANOVA with  one between-subject (Conservatism) and one within-subject (pleasant face, unpleasant face, no face), with Trust or Aesthetic as DV

q20.value: A baseline correction will be applied to the physiological signals, to remove trends and artifacts.

q21.value: we will use p-values (alpha corrected for repeated measures = 0.05 / 3) to verify our hypothesis.

q22.value: The analysis will be performed with and without the removal of outliers, defined as differing from more than 3 standard deviations from the mean. This will be done on both behavioral and physiological measures.

q23.value: We will deal with missing or incomplete data by applying a mean replacement, whenever possible.  In case this was not possible, data from that trial will be removed.

q24.value:
We may want to explore the relationship between:
- Exposure and Conservationism

attributes.title: Replication of CSPC effect (Crump, Gong & Milliken, 2006)
attributes.description: In the context of a practical course that is required for 2nd year students who aim to achieve a Bachelor's degree in Psychology, we will conduct a replication study of “The context-specific proportion congruent stroop effect: Location as a contextual cue” by MATTHEW J. C. CRUMP, ZHIYU GONG, and BRUCE MILLIKEN.

q1.value: A replication of “The context-specific proportion congruent stroop effect: Location as a contextual cue” by MATTHEW J. C. CRUMP, ZHIYU GONG, and BRUCE MILLIKEN

q2.value: Jenny Elisabeth Pierags, Franziska Korb, Andrea Beatrice Chang Escalante, Paula Böhlmann, Leonore Winkler, Anna Zachäi, Kateryna Liubchenko, Helen Lara Mayer, Maria Bartsch, Maria Pohl, Anne-Sophie Passek, Mary-Ann Jacoby, Antonia Mühlberg, Nora Richter , Sophie Marks, Isabel Jakob, Lucie Postel, Viktoria Stengel, Theresa Beneke, Rebekka Stauber, Vanessa Seefeld, Leopold Schimmank, Salma Matar, Noel Clausen, Letizia Tschetsche, Victoria Nothaft, Emma Lehnhoff, Julian Farwick, Veronica Theobald

q3.value: Our Research Questionsis: To what extend is location information relevant for the learning process underlying CSPC effect?

q4.value: The location information has an influence on the CSPC effect.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
It is a Between subject and 2R-Design. Participants will have 10 practice trials, followed by four blocks of 96 experimental trials. Each block will consist of 48 trials in each of the two location contexts, mixed randomly across the block. One of contexts is defined as “high-congruency context” while the other is the “low-congruency context”. The trials in the “high-congruency context” will consist of the presentation of 75% congruent trials and 25% incongruent trials. The “low-congruency context” will consist of 25% congruent trials and 75% incongruent trials.
There are going to be two ways of response to the color, “voice key” and “button press” because the original study just used “voice key” and we intend to verify the results with another answer modality.

q9.value: Every participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit students of Psychology at the Technische Universität Dresden. All of them are participants of the same practical course and it is the course’s requirement to attend the testing. Therefore we will control for impaired color vision but no one will be excluded prior to data collection. Participants with comprehension problems or impaired color vision will be excluded from the analysis after the testing.

q13.value: We will aim for a sample size of 60 participants. The required sample size for the replication is 16.

q14.value: We will aim for a sample size of 60 participants. The required sample size for the replication is 16.

q15.value: We will stop after all 60 subjects participated once.

question.value: The likelihood of congruency in relation to the location of the rectangle (above vs. below the fixation)

We have two indices, the interference effect and the CSPC effect.
Our experiment has two contexts, the high-congruency context (HC) and the low-congruency context (LC) and the stroop compatibility congruent (c) and incongruent (i)
Index 1: interference effect= i-c
〖(i-c)〗_HC>〖(i-c)〗_LC
Index 2: CSPC=〖(i-c)〗_HC-〖(i-c)〗_LC
We will perform a repeated measures ANOVA with the same factors as listed in study design.

q21.value: We will make inferences based on p-values.

q22.value: Participants whose error rates exceeded 20% will be excluded from all analysis. Participants with impaired color vision will be excluded from all analysis.

q23.value: Excluded trials will not be replaced for analysis. If data are missing because participants dropped out during the session or because of technical issues during the session, all data of these participants will be excluded.

q24.value: The authors of the to be replicated study used voice key as their response input measure. However, since we have a larger sample and the reason behind the use of voice key was not reported in the paper and is a less common measure in our field, we plan on adding a second condition using button press response measures. Our exploratory analyses will have response modality as an additional factor.

registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: Every participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We will aim for a sample size of 60 participants. The required sample size for the replication is 16.
registration_responses.q14: We will aim for a sample size of 60 participants. The required sample size for the replication is 16.
registration_responses.q15: We will stop after all 60 subjects participated once.
registration_responses.q21: We will make inferences based on p-values.
registration_responses.q22: Participants whose error rates exceeded 20% will be excluded from all analysis. Participants with impaired color vision will be excluded from all analysis.
registration_responses.q23: Excluded trials will not be replaced for analysis. If data are missing because participants dropped out during the session or because of technical issues during the session, all data of these participants will be excluded.
registration_responses.q24: The authors of the to be replicated study used voice key as their response input measure. However, since we have a larger sample and the reason behind the use of voice key was not reported in the paper and is a less common measure in our field, we plan on adding a second condition using button press response measures. Our exploratory analyses will have response modality as an additional factor.
registration_responses.q8.question:
It is a Between subject and 2R-Design. Participants will have 10 practice trials, followed by four blocks of 96 experimental trials. Each block will consist of 48 trials in each of the two location contexts, mixed randomly across the block. One of contexts is defined as “high-congruency context” while the other is the “low-congruency context”. The trials in the “high-congruency context” will consist of the presentation of 75% congruent trials and 25% incongruent trials. The “low-congruency context” will consist of 25% congruent trials and 75% incongruent trials.
There are going to be two ways of response to the color, “voice key” and “button press” because the original study just used “voice key” and we intend to verify the results with another answer modality.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will recruit students of Psychology at the Technische Universität Dresden. All of them are participants of the same practical course and it is the course’s requirement to attend the testing. Therefore we will control for impaired color vision but no one will be excluded prior to data collection. Participants with comprehension problems or impaired color vision will be excluded from the analysis after the testing.
registration_responses.q16.question: The likelihood of congruency in relation to the location of the rectangle (above vs. below the fixation)
registration_responses.q17.question: Reaction time and error rate.
registration_responses.q18.question:
We have two indices, the interference effect and the CSPC effect.
Our experiment has two contexts, the high-congruency context (HC) and the low-congruency context (LC) and the stroop compatibility congruent (c) and incongruent (i)
Index 1: interference effect= i-c
〖(i-c)〗_HC>〖(i-c)〗_LC
Index 2: CSPC=〖(i-c)〗_HC-〖(i-c)〗_LC
registration_responses.q19.question: We will perform a repeated measures ANOVA with the same factors as listed in study design.

attributes.description: Data from UK and US 19th March 2020

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Risk perception of COVID-19/coronavirus: evaluating the effects of communicating uncertainty around trends in death rates

other.value:
Secondary analyses: We will run exploratory analyses investigating the effects of numeracy, low vs. high education level and demographics, as different sections of the population may engage differently with the various treatments.
Furthermore, as COVID-19 is a highly emotive/current topic at the moment, we will investigate the effects that opinions and attitudes on the virus (such as state of concern and trust in/satisfaction with policies/political leaders/official communication/science) have on our measures, as well as the effects of the extent to which participants are personally affected, and their prosocial inclinations and self-efficacy views.

sample.value: We will sample 2100 participants, providing 95% power at alpha level 0.008 (adjusted to account for the six hypotheses being tested) for small effects (~ f = 0.1).

analyses.value: One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with pairwise post-hoc comparisons (adjusting for multiple comparisons using Tukey’s HSD), for each of the dependent variables, comparing the three conditions according to the expected pattern of results for each hypothesis.

outliers.value: We may exclude people who fail to answer the comprehension check correctly and/or sensibly. We will screen the data for suspicious scoring patterns (such as scoring “7” on a long consecutive series of items, including reverse coded items), and may exclude people with such scoring patterns.

dependent.value:
-	Affective reaction: 
o	How does the information you just saw make you feel? Please indicate this by dragging the slider to select a number from 0 = negative/unhappy to 10 = positive/happy.

-	Subjective comprehension: 
o	How easy or difficult do you find this graph to understand? [7-point scale: Very difficult – Very easy]

-	Objective comprehension:
o	In the UK, was the underlying death rate of the pandemic higher on day 5 than on day 20? [Yes, No, Don’t know]
o	In Italy, was the underlying death rate higher on day 13 of the pandemic or on day 22? [The underlying death rate was higher on day 13; The underlying death rate was higher on day 22; The underlying death rate was about the same on day 13 as on day 22; Don’t know]
o	How did the trend in the underlying death rate between day 2 and day 6 of the pandemic compare between Italy and the UK? [The trend was steeper in Italy; The trend was steeper in the UK; The trend was about the same; Don't know
o	In the UK, was the underlying death rate higher on day 7 of the pandemic or on day 14? [The underlying death rate was higher on day 7, The underlying death rate was higher on day 14, The underlying death rate was about the same on day 7 as on day 14, Don't know]
o	Was the increase in the death rate trend faster in the UK between day 10 and day 12 of the pandemic or between day 14 and day 16? [The rate increased faster between day 10 and day 12, The rate increased faster between day 14 and day 16, It was about the same in both time periods, Don’t know]

-	Questions designed to detect the effects of uncertainty presentation on interpretation of the trends and differences between trends:
o	What does this graph show about the death rates in Italy compared to in the UK?
     	It shows that the underlying death rate between day 12 and day 17 of the pandemic was... [7 point scale: 1 = Higher in Italy, 4 = Impossible to tell, 7= Higher in UK]
     	It shows that the increase in the death rate in the last 2 days shown on the graph was... [7 point scale: 1 = Higher in Italy, 4 = Impossible to tell, 7= Higher in UK]
     	It shows that the underlying death rate between day 2 and day 8 of the pandemic was... [7 point scale: 1 = Higher in Italy, 4 = Impossible to tell, 7= Higher in UK]

-	Perceived uncertainty:
o	To what extent do you think that the trends shown in the graph are certain or uncertain? [7 point scale: Very certain – Very uncertain]
o	How much uncertainty do you think there is about the trends shown in the graph? [10-point slider No uncertainty – A great deal of uncertainty]
o	Does this graph show any uncertainty (a range) around the trends in death rates? [Yes; No; Don’t know]
o	If you only had this graph as a reference for trends in death rates, to what extent would you think these trends were certain or uncertain? [7 point scale: Very certain – Very uncertain]

-	Perceived trustworthiness of the information: 
o	To what extent do you think the trends shown in the graph are accurate? [7-point scale: Not accurate at all – Very accurate]
o	To what extent do you think the trends shown in the graph are reliable? [7-point scale: Not reliable at all – Very reliable]
o	 To what extent do you think the trends shown in the graph are trustworthy? [7-point scale: Not trustworthy at all – Very trustworthy]

-	Perceived trustworthiness of the producer: 
o	To what extent do you think that the people responsible for producing the trends shown in the graph are trustworthy? [7-point scale: Not trustworthy at all – Very trustworthy]

hypothesis.value:
What are the effects of communicating uncertainty in two different formats (the first in the form of a 95% confidence interval; the second in the form of a scatter plot) around the trend in COVID-19 death rate in Italy and the UK on affect, the subjective and objective comprehension of the information, interpretation of the trends and differences between the trends, the perceived uncertainty of the information, the perceived trustworthiness of the information and the perceived trustworthiness of the producers of the information.

-	For subjective comprehension of the information, we expect that communicating uncertainty in both formats will decrease subjective comprehension compared to a control where no uncertainty is depicted.  

-	For objective comprehension, we expect there to be no significant difference between the uncertainty conditions and the control condition in participants’ objective comprehension.

-	For questions relating to the interpretation of the depicted trends and of differences between these trends, we expect that communicating uncertainty in both formats will increase the level of nuance in participants’ answers (e.g. participants who have not seen uncertainty information may be more likely to give more definitive answers to questions relating to the extent to which a trend changes, say, than those who have seen uncertainty information).

-	For perceived uncertainty of the information, we expect that communicating uncertainty in both formats will increase perceived uncertainty compared to the control.

-	For perceived trustworthiness of the information, we expect there to be no significant difference between the two uncertainty conditions and the control condition in perceptions of trustworthiness of the information

-	For perceived trustworthiness of the producers of the information, we expect there to be no significant difference between the two uncertainty conditions and the control condition in perceptions of trustworthiness of the source

o	Was the increase in the death rate trend faster in the UK between day 10 and day 12 of the pandemic or between day 14 and day 16? [The rate increased faster between day 10 and day 12, The rate increased faster between day 14 and day 16, It was about the same in both time periods, Don’t know]

-	Questions designed to detect the effects of uncertainty presentation on interpretation of the trends and differences between trends:
o	What does this graph show about the death rates in Italy compared to in the UK?
     	It shows that the underlying death rate between day 12 and day 17 of the pandemic was... [7 point scale: 1 = Higher in Italy, 4 = Impossible to tell, 7= Higher in UK]
     	It shows that the increase in the death rate in the last 2 days shown on the graph was... [7 point scale: 1 = Higher in Italy, 4 = Impossible to tell, 7= Higher in UK]
     	It shows that the underlying death rate between day 2 and day 8 of the pandemic was... [7 point scale: 1 = Higher in Italy, 4 = Impossible to tell, 7= Higher in UK]

-	Perceived uncertainty:
o	To what extent do you think that the trends shown in the graph are certain or uncertain? [7 point scale: Very certain – Very uncertain]
o	How much uncertainty do you think there is about the trends shown in the graph? [10-point slider No uncertainty – A great deal of uncertainty]
o	Does this graph show any uncertainty (a range) around the trends in death rates? [Yes; No; Don’t know]
o	If you only had this graph as a reference for trends in death rates, to what extent would you think these trends were certain or uncertain? [7 point scale: Very certain – Very uncertain]

-	Perceived trustworthiness of the information: 
o	To what extent do you think the trends shown in the graph are accurate? [7-point scale: Not accurate at all – Very accurate]
o	To what extent do you think the trends shown in the graph are reliable? [7-point scale: Not reliable at all – Very reliable]
o	 To what extent do you think the trends shown in the graph are trustworthy? [7-point scale: Not trustworthy at all – Very trustworthy]

-	Perceived trustworthiness of the producer: 
o	To what extent do you think that the people responsible for producing the trends shown in the graph are trustworthy? [7-point scale: Not trustworthy at all – Very trustworthy]

hypothesis.value:
What are the effects of communicating uncertainty in two different formats (the first in the form of a 95% confidence interval; the second in the form of a scatter plot) around the trend in COVID-19 death rate in Italy and the UK on affect, the subjective and objective comprehension of the information, interpretation of the trends and differences between the trends, the perceived uncertainty of the information, the perceived trustworthiness of the information and the perceived trustworthiness of the producers of the information.

-	For subjective comprehension of the information, we expect that communicating uncertainty in both formats will decrease subjective comprehension compared to a control where no uncertainty is depicted.  

-	For objective comprehension, we expect there to be no significant difference between the uncertainty conditions and the control condition in participants’ objective comprehension.

-	For questions relating to the interpretation of the depicted trends and of differences between these trends, we expect that communicating uncertainty in both formats will increase the level of nuance in participants’ answers (e.g. participants who have not seen uncertainty information may be more likely to give more definitive answers to questions relating to the extent to which a trend changes, say, than those who have seen uncertainty information).

-	For perceived uncertainty of the information, we expect that communicating uncertainty in both formats will increase perceived uncertainty compared to the control.

-	For perceived trustworthiness of the information, we expect there to be no significant difference between the two uncertainty conditions and the control condition in perceptions of trustworthiness of the information

-	For perceived trustworthiness of the producers of the information, we expect there to be no significant difference between the two uncertainty conditions and the control condition in perceptions of trustworthiness of the source

registration_responses.name: Risk perception of COVID-19/coronavirus: evaluating the effects of communicating uncertainty around trends in death rates
registration_responses.other:
Secondary analyses: We will run exploratory analyses investigating the effects of numeracy, low vs. high education level and demographics, as different sections of the population may engage differently with the various treatments.
Furthermore, as COVID-19 is a highly emotive/current topic at the moment, we will investigate the effects that opinions and attitudes on the virus (such as state of concern and trust in/satisfaction with policies/political leaders/official communication/science) have on our measures, as well as the effects of the extent to which participants are personally affected, and their prosocial inclinations and self-efficacy views.
registration_responses.sample: We will sample 2100 participants, providing 95% power at alpha level 0.008 (adjusted to account for the six hypotheses being tested) for small effects (~ f = 0.1).
registration_responses.analyses: One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with pairwise post-hoc comparisons (adjusting for multiple comparisons using Tukey’s HSD), for each of the dependent variables, comparing the three conditions according to the expected pattern of results for each hypothesis.
registration_responses.outliers: We may exclude people who fail to answer the comprehension check correctly and/or sensibly. We will screen the data for suspicious scoring patterns (such as scoring “7” on a long consecutive series of items, including reverse coded items), and may exclude people with such scoring patterns.
